isis.stitle: International® MaxxForce™ DT, 9 and 10 Engine Service Manual - Terminology - Terminology

svcproc.title: Service Procedure

deflist.def: The work per cycle required to drive engine accessories (normally, only those essential to engine operation).
A device that performs work in response to an input signal.
The entrainment of air or combustion gas in coolant, lubricant, or fuel.

A heat exchanger mounted in the charge air path between the turbocharger and engine intake manifold. The aftercooler reduces the charge air temperature by transferring heat from the charge air to a cooling medium (usually air).

The environmental air temperature in which a unit is operating. In general, the temperature is measured in the shade (no solar radiation) and represents the air temperature for other engine cooling performance measurement purposes. Air entering the radiator may or may not be the same ambient due to possible heating from other sources or recirculation. (SAE J1004 SEP81)
The standard unit for measuring the strength of an electrical current. The flow rate of a charge in a conductor or conducting medium of one coulomb per second. (SAE J1213 NOV82)
A continuously variable voltage.
A circuit in the ECM processing section that converts an analog signal (DC or AC) to a usable digital signal for the microprocessor.
A serial datalink specified by the American Trucking Association and the SAE.
1. The pressure of the charge air leaving the turbocharger.

svcproc.para: 2. Inlet manifold pressure that is greater than atmospheric pressure. Obtained by turbocharging.

deflist.def: The lowest position of the piston during the stroke.

The power output from an engine, not the indicated horsepower. The power output of an engine, sometimes-called flywheel horsepower is less than the indicated horsepower by the amount of friction horsepower consumed in the engine.
Net brake horsepower is measured with all engine components. The power of an engine when configured as a fully equipped engine. (SAE J1349 JUN90)

The data values used by the strategy to solve equations and make decisions. Calibration values are stored in ROM and put into the processor during programming to allow the engine to operate within certain parameters.
A substance that produces a chemical reaction without undergoing a chemical change itself.

An antipollution device in the exhaust system that contains a catalyst for chemically converting some pollutants in the exhaust gases (carbon monoxide, unburned hydrocarbons, and oxides of nitrogen) into harmless compounds.
A dynamic condition in a fluid system that forms gas-filled bubbles (cavities) in the fluid.
1. The auto-ignition quality of diesel fuel.

svcproc.para: 2. A rating applied to diesel fuel similar to octane rating for gasoline.
3. A measure of how readily diesel fuel starts to burn (self-ignites) at high compression temperature.

Diesel fuel with a high cetane number self-ignites shortly after injection into the combustion chamber. Therefore, it has a short ignition delay time. Diesel fuel with a low cetane number resists self-ignition. Therefore, it has a longer ignition delay time.

deflist.def: Dense, pressurized, heated air discharged from the turbocharger.
See Aftercooler.
A crankcase ventilation that recycles crankcase gases through a breather, then back to the clean air intake.
A system that uses a sensor to provide feedback to the ECM. The ECM uses the sensor to continuously monitor variables and adjust to match engine requirements.
The point when wax crystals occur in fuel, making fuel cloudy or hazy. Usually below -12 °C (10 °F).
The sustained constant current (in amperes) needed to produce a minimum terminal voltage under a load of 7.2 volts per battery after 30 seconds.
An ECM function that continuously monitors the inputs and outputs to ensure that readings are within set limits.
A fluid used to transport heat from one point to another.
A switch sensor used to indicate low coolant level.
The housing that encloses the crankshaft, connecting rods, and allied parts.
A vent for the crankcase to release excess interior air pressure.
The force of air inside the crankcase against the crankcase housing.
The flow of electrons passing through a conductor. Measured in amperes.
A device that reduces the amplitude of torsional vibration. (SAE J1479 JAN85)
The removal or purging of gases (air or combustion gas) entrained in coolant or lubricating oil.
A separate tank in the cooling system used for one or more of the following functions:
Formerly called a Fault Code or Flash Code. A DTC is a three digit numeric code used for troubleshooting.

An electronic meter that uses a digital display to indicate a measured value. Preferred for use on microprocessor systems because it has a very high internal impedance and will not load down the circuit being measured.
A computer decision that deactivates a system and prevents operation of the system.
The stroke of the piston multiplied by the area of the cylinder bore multiplied by the number of cylinders in the engine.
A transistor within an electronic module that controls the power to an actuator circuit.
A transistor within an electronic module that controls the ground to an actuator circuit.
A control signal that has a controlled on/off time measurement from 0 to 100%. Normally used to control solenoids.
An instrument panel lamp that comes on when DTCs are set. DTCs can be read as flash codes (red and amber instrument panel lamps).
Tests that are done with the ignition switch ON and the engine OFF.
Engine rating includes Rated hp and Rated rpm.
Tests done with the engine running.
A brake device using engine exhaust back pressure as a retarding medium.
Exhaust gases flow through the exhaust manifold to the turbocharger exhaust inlet and are directed to the EGR cooler.

An alternate control strategy that reduces adverse effects that can be caused by a system failure. If a sensor fails, the ECM substitutes a good sensor signal or assumed sensor value in its place. A lit amber instrument panel lamp signals that the vehicle needs service.
A blockage, usually from contaminants, that prevents the flow of fluid through a filter.
See Diagnostic Trouble Code (DTC).
A blockage, usually from contaminants, that prevents the flow of fluid through the fuel inlet line.
The force that the fuel exerts on the fuel system as it is pumped through the fuel system.
A pre-filter in the fuel system that keeps larger contaminants from entering the fuel system.

A fully equipped engine is an engine equipped with only those accessories necessary to perform its intended service. A fully equipped engine does not include components that are used to power auxiliary systems. If these components are integral with the engine or for any reason are included on the test engine, the power absorbed may be determined and added to the net brake power. (SAE J1995 JUN90)
A fusible link is a special section of low tension cable designed to open the circuit when subjected to an extreme current overload. (SAE J1156 APR86)
The maximum percent grade which the vehicle can transverse for a specified time at a specified speed. The gradeability limit is the grade upon which the vehicle can just move forward. (SAE J227a)
Maximum combined weight of towing vehicle (including passengers and cargo) and the trailer. The GCWR indicates the maximum loaded weight that the vehicle is allowed to tow.
The power of a complete basic engine, with air cleaner, without fan, and alternator and air compressor not charging.
The development of a transverse electric potential gradient in a current-carrying conductor or semiconductor when a magnetic field is applied.
Generates a digital on/off signal that indicates speed and timing.
Inputs to the ECM from a sensor that generates varying frequencies (engine speed and vehicle speed sensors).
Horsepower is the unit of work done in a given period of time, equal to 33,000 pounds multiplied by one foot per minute. 1hp = 33,000 lb x 1 ft /1 min.
Unburned or partially burned fuel molecules.

item.para: Low idle is minimum rpm at no load.
High idle is maximum rpm at no load.

deflist.def: A collection of tubes through which the fuel-air mixture flows from the fuel injector to the intake valves of the cylinders.

deflist.term: International NGV Tool Utilized for Next Generation Electronics (INTUNE)
deflist.def: The diagnostics software for chassis related components and systems.

Switched sensor inputs that generate an on/off (high/low) signal to the ECM. The input to the ECM from the sensor could be from a high input source switch (usually 5 or 12 volts) or from a grounding switch that grounds the signal from a current limiting resistor in the ECM that creates a low signal (0 volts).
Lubricity is the ability of a substance to reduce friction between solid surfaces in relative motion under loaded conditions.
A condition when the engine is operating at or below maximum torque speed.
A double-leg liquid-column gauge, or a single inclined gauge, used to measure the difference between two fluid pressures. Typically, a manometer records in inches of water.
The diagnostics software for engine related components and systems.
An integrated circuit in a microcomputer that controls information flow.
Nitrogen oxides form by a reaction between nitrogen and oxygen at high temperatures and pressures in the combustion chamber.
Refers to a switch that remains closed when no control force is acting on it.
Refers to a switch that remains open when no control force is acting on it.
The unit of resistance. One ohm is the value of resistance through which a potential of one volt will maintain a current of one ampere. (SAE J1213 NOV82)
A self test that the technician initiates using the EST and is run from a program in the processor.
An On demand test done during an Engine OFF self test to check the continuity of selected actuators.
A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a solution.
Particulate matter includes mostly burned particles of fuel and engine oil.
An instrument for measuring fluid pressure.
Power is a measure of the rate at which work is done. Compare with Torque.
Accessory output, usually from the transmission, used to power a hydraulic pump for a special auxiliary feature (garbage packing, lift equipment, etc).
The time that an actuator, such as an injector, remains energized.

Computer memory that stores information. Information can be written to and read from RAM. Input information (current engine speed or temperature) can be stored in RAM to be compared to values stored in Read Only Memory (ROM). All memory in RAM is lost when the ignition switch is turned off.
Engine gross horsepower at rated speed as declared by the manufacturer. (SAE J1995 JUN90)
Maximum brake horsepower output of an engine as certified by the engine manufacturer. The power of an engine when configured as a basic engine. (SAE J1995 JUN90)
Engine net horsepower at rated speed as declared by the manufacturer. (SAE J1349 JUN90)
The speed, as determined by the manufacturer, at which the engine is rated. (SAE J1995 JUN90)
Maximum torque produced by an engine as certified by the manufacturer.

In a Micro Strain Gauge (MSG) sensor pressure to be measured exerts force on a pressure vessel that stretches and compresses to change resistance of strain gauges bonded to the surface of the pressure vessel. Internal sensor electronics convert the changes in resistance to a ratiometric voltage output.
A 5 volt reference supplied by the ECM to operate the engine sensors.
Time in minutes that a fully charged battery can be discharged to 10.5 volts at 25 amperes.
The common ground wire to the ECM for the sensors.
A set of switches used for cruise control, Power TakeOff (PTO), and remote hand throttle system.
An engine operating at a constant speed and load and at stabilized temperatures and pressures. (SAE J215 JAN80)

A plan or set of operating instructions that the microprocessor follows for a desired goal. Strategy is the computer program itself, including all equations and decision making logic. Strategy is always stored in ROM and cannot be changed during calibration.
Stroke is the movement of the piston from Top Dead Center (TDC) to Bottom Dead Center (BDC).
Material that supports the washcoating or catalytic materials.
The static pressure differential that occurs at a given air flow from air entrance through air exit in a system. Usually measured in inches (millimeters) of water. (SAE J1004 SEP81)
Engine speed signal for remote tachometers.
A semiconductor device. A sensing element that changes resistance as the temperature changes.
A thrust load pushes or reacts through a bearing in a direction parallel to the shaft.
The uppermost position of the piston during the stroke.

A force having a twisting or turning effect. For a single force, the cross product of a vector from some reference point to the point of application of the force within the force itself. Also known as moment of force or rotation moment. Torque is a measure of the ability of an engine to do work.

deflist.term: Truck Computer Analysis of Performance and Economy (TCAPE)
deflist.def: Truck Computer Analysis of Performance and Economy is a computer program that simulates the performance and fuel economy of trucks.
A turbine driven compressor mounted to the exhaust manifold. The turbocharger increases the pressure, temperature and density of intake air to charge air.
A variable capacitance sensor is measures pressure. The pressure forces a ceramic material closer to a thin metal disc in the sensor, changing the capacitance of the sensor.
The computer system used to program electronically controlled vehicles.
Output from the ECM to a vehicle retarder.
Normally a magnetic pickup sensor mounted in the tailshaft housing of the transmission, used to indicate ground speed.
The internal resistance to the flow of any fluid.
A fan drive that is activated when a thermostat, sensing high air temperature, forces fluid through a special coupling. The fluid activates the fan.
A unit of electromotive force that will move a current of one ampere through a resistance of one Ohm.
Electrical potential expressed in volts.
Reduction in applied voltage from the current flowing through a circuit or portion of the circuit current multiplied by resistance.
Voltage supplied by the ignition switch when the key is ON.
A layer of alumina applied to the substrate in a monolith-type converter.
